markdownRemark.html:
yet another 90s kid that stumbled into web development...

for me, it was pretty much:

  1. angelfire/tripod
  2. myspace/microsoft frontpage

Before the social media of now, I remember there were just chat rooms, newletters, and discussion boards if you wanted to feel social online before 2002.

My first websites were basically created to share my hobbies and discuss them with others when I was like 12. I really wanted to get into more music so I created some tripod site with a template that had widgets for sh*t like a guest book to get punk band recommendations. ðŸ˜‚

Then, I got into skateboarding and created a new tripod site to try to start a skateboarding club to put a skate video together with local skaters. Later, we connected on myspace and became friends IRL. Without any more motivation to create tripod sites (everyone was on myspace), I moved onto creating custom myspace layouts for friends. I am still pretty proud of them and even got paid for some around 2008/2009. The timing for that was sort of funny because FB overtook myspace in popularity like two months later.

By then, I had taken a computer science (java) class and 2 web design classes in high school to write somewhat cleaner markup/css and think of more complex programming stuff. I enjoyed getting better and uh, well, here I am.

dude, shout out to other services around at that time: putfile, garageband, AIM
